articles.headline: Two Refugees, Both on Poland’s Border. But Worlds Apart.
articles.snippet: A young man fleeing war in Sudan and a young woman evacuating Ukraine crossed into Poland at the same time. They had very different experiences.
articles.abstract: A young man fleeing war in Sudan and a young woman evacuating Ukraine crossed into Poland at the same time. They had very different experiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUZNICA, Poland — On the day war broke out in Ukraine, Albagir, a 22-year-old refugee from Sudan, was lying on the frozen forest floor at the gateway to Poland, trying to stay alive.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Monika Pronczuk

articles.headline: He’s American, He Oversees Papa John’s in Russia and He’s Staying
articles.snippet: Christopher Wynne’s company controls the franchise agreements for the 190 Papa John’s locations in the country. “At the end of the day, they appreciate a good pizza,” he said.
articles.abstract: Christopher Wynne’s company controls the franchise agreements for the 190 Papa John’s locations in the country. “At the end of the day, they appreciate a good pizza,” he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Papa John’s International said last week that it was suspending all of its corporate operations in Russia, following in the footsteps of other high-profile American brands like McDonald’s and Starbucks.

articles.headline: Diplomacy Quickens to Halt Ukraine War or Stop Its Expansion
articles.snippet: Ukraine and Russia held a new round of talks and agreed to resume them on Tuesday, as the United States warned China about helping an increasingly isolated Kremlin and expanding the conflict.
articles.abstract: Ukraine and Russia held a new round of talks and agreed to resume them on Tuesday, as the United States warned China about helping an increasingly isolated Kremlin and expanding the conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Diplomatic activity quickened on multiple fronts Monday as Russia’s war on Ukraine entered an uncertain new phase, with President Vladimir V. Putin’s forces widening their bombardment of Kyiv and other cities, hundreds of civilians escaping the devastated port of Mariupol, and the United States warning China over its deepening alignment with an isolated Russia.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Document in Jan. 6 Case Shows Plan to Storm Government Buildings
articles.snippet: New details from evidence cited in the indictment of Enrique Tarrio, the former head of the far-right Proud Boys, reveal a plan with similarities to what unfolded at the Capitol.
articles.abstract: New details from evidence cited in the indictment of Enrique Tarrio, the former head of the far-right Proud Boys, reveal a plan with similarities to what unfolded at the Capitol.
articles.lead_paragraph: A document found by federal prosecutors in the possession of a far-right leader contained a detailed plan to surveil and storm government buildings around the Capitol on Jan. 6 last year, people familiar with the document said on Monday.

articles.headline: How California Is Building the Nation’s First Privacy Police
articles.snippet: A new state agency has a $10 million budget to regulate Google, Facebook and others. But first it needs to be created.
articles.abstract: A new state agency has a $10 million budget to regulate Google, Facebook and others. But first it needs to be created.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ashkan Soltani, the head of California’s new online privacy regulator, needed help launching the first agency of its kind in the United States. So he called the state’s Horse Racing Board.

articles.headline: Oakland Cannabis Sellers, Once Full of Hope, Face a Harsh Reality
articles.snippet: The cannabis industry, designed in part to help communities upended by the war on drugs, is being threatened by theft, racism and a market that is stacked against small operators.
articles.abstract: The cannabis industry, designed in part to help communities upended by the war on drugs, is being threatened by theft, racism and a market that is stacked against small operators.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Across from where the Athletics play baseball sits a two-story concrete building painted bright orange and white. It is home to a cannabis dispensary called Blunts and Moore.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jim Wilson

articles.headline: China’s Covid Lockdowns Set to Further Disrupt Global Supply Chains
articles.snippet: A surge in Omicron variant infections has prompted Chinese authorities to lock down residents, close factories and stop truck traffic, snarling already frayed supply chains.
articles.abstract: A surge in Omicron variant infections has prompted Chinese authorities to lock down residents, close factories and stop truck traffic, snarling already frayed supply chains.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Trucks are being delayed by the testing of drivers. Container rates are rising as ships wait for many hours at ports. Products are piling up in warehouses.

articles.headline: Global Economy Sinks Deeper Into Turmoil as Fed Prepares to Raise Rates
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials are set to raise interest rates to control inflation, but the return to normal they had hoped to see remains painfully elusive.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials are set to raise interest rates to control inflation, but the return to normal they had hoped to see remains painfully elusive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Federal Reserve officials raise interest rates on Wednesday, they will do so amid an unfortunate economic reality: Many of the inflationary pressures they had long assumed would dissipate have instead lingered, and some are getting worse.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Jeanna Smialek
